messages.text:
I'm sure there's a reason for this, but why does `x == x` not return `true` for symbolic variables?
```julia> using Symbolics

julia> @variables x
(x,)

julia> x == x
x == x```

elements.text: I'm sure there's a reason for this, but why does

true
for symbolic variables?

messages.text: I was curious as to how NeuralPDE.jl calculated higher order derivatives, so I had a peek. Does it use numeric gradients (<https://github.com/SciML/NeuralPDE.jl/blob/c93e05192d4023f5eaa8bff566b739d090a9816a/src/pinns_pde_solve.jl#L483|GitHub link>)? Tensorflow/PyTorch implementations of PINNs tend to use AD, I think? I was curious of the pros and cons of either approach. I thought the ability to AD all the things was part of the appeal of PINNS, though I'm probably missing something---I'm not so savvy with understanding the implications of AD and higher order derivatives.

messages.text:
Question about `ModelingToolkit` and `Symbolics` : I’m trying to take the limit of an expression involving special functions and their derivatives.
I figured that `SymbolicUtils.@rule`  was the way to go. However, the limit is different depending on of the arguments (e.g. lim d-> 0 bessel( nu, k) depends on nu).

I tried this
```using SymbolicUtils._iszero
SymbolicUtils.@rule besselk(~ν,~τ) => SymbolicUtils.ifelse(~ν::_iszero, -log(τ), gamma(~ν)*^((1/2*~τ),-1*~ν) )```
but doesn’t work and I can’t figure it out

elements.text: Question about
ModelingToolkit
and
Symbolics

SymbolicUtils.@rule besselk(~ν,~τ) => SymbolicUtils.ifelse(~ν::_iszero, -log(τ), gamma(~ν)*^((1/2*~τ),-1*~ν) )
but doesn’t work and I can’t figure it out

messages.text: When doing Forward Sensitivity analysis by solving the sensitivity ODE of the form `u' = f(u,p,t)` I cant seem to understand what the vector of sensibilities should be. I understood the jacobian and the parameter derivatives relative to f. But what should `du/dpᵢ` be?

elements.text: When doing Forward Sensitivity analysis by solving the sensitivity ODE of the form
u' = f(u,p,t)
I cant seem to understand what the vector of sensibilities should be. I understood the jacobian and the parameter derivatives relative to f. But what should
du/dpᵢ
be?

messages.text: the derivative of the output w.r.t. a parameter.

elements.text: the derivative of the output w.r.t. a parameter.

messages.text: it's the sensitivity itself.

elements.text: it's the sensitivity itself.

messages.text:
But what should the "u0" be?
1 for all functions in f?

elements.text:
But what should the "u0" be?
1 for all functions in f?

messages.text: it's du(t)/dp_i

elements.text: it's du(t)/dp_i

messages.text: so u0 = du(0)/dp_i

elements.text: so u0 = du(0)/dp_i

messages.text: the derivative of the initial condition w.r.t. the parameter

elements.text: the derivative of the initial condition w.r.t. the parameter

messages.text: which is zero if you do stuff like `u0 = [2.0, ...]`

elements.text: which is zero if you do stuff like

messages.text: and so the initial condition of the sensitivities would then be `0` in those cases.

elements.text: and so the initial condition of the sensitivities would then be
in those cases.

messages.text:
Greetings, members of <#CN04R7WKE|sciml-bridged> 
The SciML ecosystem looks really interesting, and the tutorials are one of the best crafted I know of
If you don't mind, I've a few questions
1. Where does the ML fit in SciML? 
2. What are some of the applications of SciML? Are there any beginner friendly real-life projects for SciML?（Those'd make things a lot clearer）

elements.text: Greetings, members of

The SciML ecosystem looks really interesting, and the tutorials are one of the best crafted I know of
If you don't mind, I've a few questions
Where does the ML fit in SciML?
What are some of the applications of SciML? Are there any beginner friendly real-life projects for SciML?（Those'd make things a lot clearer）

messages.text:
> Where does the ML fit in SciML?
ML is one of the pieces put together into the models, and in a few cases there are ways to use SciML tools to solve some ML problems, but generally SciML is a user of ML but not the other way around.

elements.text: Where does the ML fit in SciML?
ML is one of the pieces put together into the models, and in a few cases there are ways to use SciML tools to solve some ML problems, but generally SciML is a user of ML but not the other way around.

messages.text:
> What are some of the applications of SciML? Are there any beginner friendly real-life projects for SciML?（Those'd make things a lot clearer）
Things like <https://arxiv.org/abs/2001.04385> . Generally, scientific computing applications.

messages.text:
I think the docs (<https://diffeqflux.sciml.ai/dev/>) for diffeq should really follow the general outline in the introduction:
```
Neural networks can be defined where the "activations" are nonlinear functions described by differential equations
Neural networks can be defined where some layers are ODE solves
ODEs can be defined where some terms are neural networks
Cost functions on ODEs can define neural networks```

elements.text: I think the docs (
) for diffeq should really follow the general outline in the introduction:

Neural networks can be defined where the "activations" are nonlinear functions described by differential equations
Neural networks can be defined where some layers are ODE solves
ODEs can be defined where some terms are neural networks
Cost functions on ODEs can define neural networks
